Schedule 7: SUBCONTRACTORS Schedule 8: benchmarking – NOT USED Schedule 9: DATA PROTECTION The Parties recognise that either Party may act as a Data Controller of Personal Data that is exchanged between the Parties as a result of the Services and/or in connection with its obligations under the Agreement.

The Parties also recognise that the Supplier may act as a Data Processor of University Personal Data that comes into its possession as a result of the provision of the Services to the University or in connection with its performance of its obligations under the Agreement and that such Processing must be in accordance with Data Protection Law.

As such, the Parties agree to comply with the terms of this Schedule. interpretation In this Schedule: Data Controller, Data Processor, Data Subject, Personal Data, Personal Data Breach and Processing shall bear the respective meanings given to them in Data Protection Law (and Process and Processes shall be construed accordingly);

Data Protection Law means all applicable data protection and privacy legislation in force from time to time which apply to a Party including the UK General Data Protection Regulation (as defined in The Data Protection, Privacy and Electronic Communications (Amendments etc) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019), the General Data Protection Regulation ((EU) 2016/679) (“EU GDPR”), the Data Protection Act 2018, the Privacy and Electronic Communications Directive 2002/58/EC (as updated by Directive 2009/136/EC), the Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations 2003 (SI 2003/2426) and all Applicable Law in any jurisdiction relating to the processing or protection of personal data and privacy, including where applicable the guidance and codes of practice issued by the Information Commissioner or relevant supervisory authority from time to time;

Description of Processing means the description of Processing as set out at Annex 1 of this Schedule; Permitted Purpose means the processing of the Shared Personal Data exchanged between the Parties in relation to the Agreement: (i) for the purpose of the provision of the Services and/or in connection with its obligations under this Agreement; (ii) for the purpose of complying with all legal and regulatory obligations, including (without limitation) to comply with Data Protection Law; and (iii) for any other purpose agreed between the Parties in writing from time to time;

Shared Personal Data means the Personal Data collected or processed by either Party in connection with the provision of the Services and/or its obligations under the Agreement and for which it acts as a Data Controller, including but not limited to the Personal Data described in Annex 2; and

University Data Protection Policies means the Applicable Policies which relate to data security or usage. GENERAL Each Party must ensure compliance with applicable Data Protection Law at all times during the Contract Term of this Agreement.

Each Party shall appoint a single point of contact ("SPoC") who will work together to reach an agreement with regards to any issues arising from the data sharing and processing arrangements set out in this Schedule to actively improve the effectiveness of such arrangements. The contact details for each of the Parties (or such other persons or contact details as a Party may specify from time to time by notice in writing to the other Party) are:

Supplier: [INSERT NAME, ROLE AND CONTACT DETAILS] University: [INSERT NAME, ROLE AND CONTACT DETAILS] If during the Contract Term the Data Protection Laws change in a way that this Schedule is no longer adequate for the purpose of governing lawful data sharing and/or processing exercises, the Parties agree that the SPoCs will negotiate in good faith to review the Schedule in the light of the new legislation.

The Parties shall review the effectiveness of this Schedule every twelve (12) months, having consideration to the Permitted Purposes and the aims and purposes set out in Annex 1 and Annex 2. The Parties shall continue or amend the Schedule depending on the outcome of this review. The review of the effectiveness will involve:

assessing whether the Description of Data Sharing attached at Annex 2 accurately sets out the Shared Personal Data exchanged between the Parties and the purposes for which the Shared Personal Data is being processed;

assessing whether the Description of Processing attached at Annex 1 hereto is an accurate description of the Processing undertaken pursuant to the Agreement; assessing whether the legal framework governing data quality, retention, and Data Subjects' rights are being complied with; and

assessing whether Personal Data Breaches involving University Personal Data and/or Shared Personal Data have been handled in accordance with this Schedule and the applicable legal framework. BOTH PARTIES AS DATA CONTROLLERS

Save as for where the Supplier is acting as a Data Processor in accordance with paragraph 4 of this Schedule, the Parties acknowledge and agree that each Party will act as a Data Controller of the Shared Personal Data exchanged or obtained as a result of or in connection with its obligations under the Agreement to which this paragraph 3 applies.

The Parties acknowledge and agree that the Description of Data Sharing attached at Annex 2 hereto is an accurate description of the Shared Personal Data exchanged between the Parties and the lawful grounds for which the Shared Personal Data is processed pursuant to the Agreement. The Parties acknowledge and agree that the Shared Personal Data must not be irrelevant or excessive with regard to the Permitted Purposes.

To the extent that either Party acts as a Data Controller of Shared Personal Data, that Party shall be responsible for the compliance obligations imposed on a Data Controller under Data Protection Law.

The Supplier represents, warrants and undertakes that: it will only process the Shared Personal Data for the Permitted Purposes (and for no other purpose whatsoever), and at all times in accordance with all applicable Data Protection Laws;

it will not do anything that causes or is likely to cause the University to be in breach of the Data Protection Law; it is entitled to provide the Shared Personal Data to the University, and it will ensure that the Shared Personal Data is accurate; and

it will not use the Shared Personal Data for direct marketing purposes at any time. The Supplier shall (and ensure that any of Supplier Personnel shall): process the Shared Personal Data fairly and lawfully and in accordance with Data Protection Law;

in respect of Shared Personal Data, ensure that it provides clear and sufficient information to the Data Subjects in accordance with Data Protection Law, of the purposes for which it will process their Personal Data, the legal basis for such purposes and such other information as is required by Data Protection Law;

not retain or process the Shared Personal Data for longer than is necessary to carry out the Permitted Purpose; only process the Shared Personal Data on the basis of one or more of the lawful grounds as set out in Annex 2;

take all reasonably necessary steps to ensure the reliability of any Supplier Personnel who have access to the Shared Personal Data; ensure that the Supplier Personnel are appropriately trained to handle and process the Shared Personal Data in accordance with the technical and organisational security measures described in this Schedule (including the measures set out in Annex 3) together with any other applicable Data Protection Laws. The level, content and regularity of such training shall be proportionate to the Supplier Personnel's role, responsibility and frequency with respect to their handling and processing of the Shared Personal Data;

notify the University promptly (and in any event within 2 Business Days) following its receipt of any request made by a Data Subject pursuant to their rights under the Data Protection Laws or any correspondence received from a supervisory authority regarding the Shared Personal Data, and provide such information, co-operation and assistance as the University may reasonably require in relation to such request or correspondence within any time limits imposed under Data Protection Laws;

not disclose or transfer the Shared Personal Data to a third party located outside of the United Kingdom and/or European Economic Area unless it complies with the provisions of applicable Data Protection Law;

keep detailed, accurate and up-to-date records relating to its processing of the Shared Personal Data; and ensure that Shared Personal Data is either returned to the University, transferred to a Replacement Provider on the University’s written instructions and at all times in accordance with Good Industry Practice and Applicable Law, or disposed of in a secure manner such that the Shared Personal Data is not recoverable on termination of this Agreement or once processing of the Shared Personal Data is no longer necessary for the Permitted Purposes it was originally shared for.

In the event of a dispute or claim brought by a Data Subject, the Information Commissioner or a supervisory authority concerning the processing of Shared Personal Data against either or both Parties, the Parties will promptly inform each other about any such disputes or claims, and will cooperate with a view to settling them amicably in a timely fashion.

The Parties agree to respond to any generally available non-binding mediation procedure initiated by a Data Subject, the Information Commissioner or a supervisory authority. If they do participate in the proceedings, the Parties may elect to do so remotely (such as by telephone or other electronic means). The Parties also agree to consider participating in any other arbitration, mediation or other dispute resolution proceedings developed for data protection disputes.

Each Party shall abide by a decision of a competent court of England and Wales or of the Information Commissioner or another relevant supervisory authority. SUPPLIER AS DATA PROCESSOR ON BEHALF OF THE UNIVERSITY

The Parties acknowledge and agree that the Supplier may act as a Data Processor of University Personal Data as a result of its provision of the Services under this Agreement for the purposes of Data Protection Law to which this paragraph 4 applies.

The Parties acknowledge and agree that the Description of Processing attached at Annex 1 hereto is an accurate description of the Processing undertaken pursuant to the Agreement. If and to the extent that the Supplier or any Supplier Personnel Processes any the University Personal Data, it shall:

only Process any the University Personal Data for the purposes of supplying the Services (and for no other purpose whatsoever) and at all times in accordance with Good Industry Practice, the University's written instructions from time to time, the Description of Processing, the University Data Protection Policies, and all applicable Data Protection Laws;

not transfer, or otherwise directly or indirectly disclose, any the University Personal Data to countries outside the United Kingdom and/or European Economic Area without the prior written consent of the University which may be refused or granted subject to such conditions as the University deems necessary, except where the Supplier is required to transfer the University Personal Data by the laws of the member states of the EU or EU law (and shall inform the University of that legal requirement before the transfer, unless those laws prevent it doing so);

provide to the University at any time on request a detailed written description of the technical and organisational measures in place to protect the University Personal Data; promptly (and in any event within 2 Business Days) and fully notify the University in writing of any notices received by it relating to the Processing of any the University Personal Data, including any requests, complaints or correspondence. The Supplier shall provide and implement technical and organisational measures to help the University fulfil its obligations in relation to such notices from or on behalf of Data Subjects in connection with the rights conferred on them by Data Protection Law;

promptly (and in any event within 24 hours) and fully notify the University in writing of any actual or potential Personal Data Breach involving University Personal Data or if any the University Personal Data has been disclosed in breach of this Schedule, or if it is lost, becomes corrupted, is damaged or is deleted in error;

make available to the University all information necessary to demonstrate compliance with the obligations set out in this Schedule and permit the University (and any of its authorised representatives) access to any of the Supplier’s premises, personnel, IT systems and relevant records as may be reasonably required by the University upon reasonable notice at any time for the purposes of conducting an audit in order to verify the Supplier’s compliance with this Schedule and Data Protection Laws. The Supplier shall provide the University (and/or their authorised representatives) with all reasonable co-operation, access and assistance in relation to each audit;

promptly provide such information and assistance (at no cost to University) as the University may require in relation to: the implementation and maintenance of security measures to protect University Personal Data and the privacy of Data Subjects;

the University’s decision to undertake a data protection impact assessment where the University considers (in its sole discretion) that the type of Processing may result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of Data Subjects;

any request from or on behalf of any Data Subject for: access, rectification or erasure of University Personal Data, or any complaint, objection to Processing, or other correspondence. In no event shall the Supplier or any of the Supplier Personnel respond directly to any such request, complaint or correspondence without the University’s prior written consent unless and to the extent required by law; and

any approval of the Information Commissioner or other data protection supervisory authority to any Processing of University Personal Data, or any request, notice or investigation by such supervisory authority. not, by any act or omission, cause the University to breach any Data Protection Law; and

on request at any time and on the expiry or termination of this Agreement, it shall (at no cost to the University) at the University’s option either return to the University all the University Personal Data and/or Confidential Information, and copies of it in such format as the University may require or securely dispose of the University Personal Data and/or Confidential Information, except to the extent that any Applicable Law requires the Supplier to store such University Personal Data and the Supplier has promptly demonstrated their legal requirements to the University.

In the Supplier’s reasonable opinion, to the extent that it believes that any instruction received by it is likely to infringe the Data Protection Law or any other Applicable Law, the Supplier shall promptly inform the University.

If the University provides consent in accordance with paragraph 4.3.2, the Supplier shall ensure that, before any University Personal Data is transferred, directly or indirectly disclosed or made available to any countries outside the United Kingdom and/or the European Economic Area, such transfer complies with Data Protection Law, including (if applicable) validly executing (or, where applicable, shall ensure that a Data Third Party authorised by the University in accordance with paragraph 4.6.1 validly executes) standard contractual clauses approved by the European Commission for the transfer of personal data to third countries pursuant to the EU GDPR (or such applicable alternative version of those clauses issued by the European Commission, the Information Commissioner’s Office, or another relevant supervisory authority from time to time) and any supplemental clauses and/or risk assessments that may be required from time to time. This paragraph 4.5 shall be without prejudice to any other conditions that the University may deem necessary in accordance with paragraph 4.3.2.

The Supplier: shall not permit any Processing of University Personal Data by any agent or subcontractor or other third party (Data Third Parties) without the prior written authorisation of University and only then subject to such conditions as University may require and provided the Supplier remains fully liable for all the actions and omissions of the Data Third Party and that any Data Third Party agrees in writing to comply with obligations substantially the same as those imposed on the Supplier in this Schedule; and

ensure that access to the University Personal Data is limited to those of the Supplier Personnel or authorised Data Third Parties who need access to it to supply the Services and that all Supplier Personnel and authorised Data Third Parties are:

informed of the confidential nature of the University Personal Data, and that they must not disclose the University Personal Data; are subject to an enforceable obligation of confidence with regards to the University Personal Data; and

are assessed by the Supplier or authorised Data Third Parties prior to any Processing of University Personal Data to ensure their reliability, and that they receive training on data protection matters.

The Supplier shall (at no cost to the University) restore or recreate (in a timely manner and in accordance with Good Industry Practice) all the University Personal Data which is lost, deleted or corrupted by the Supplier or any of the Supplier Personnel in breach of this Schedule.

DATA SECURITY The Supplier shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to protect University Personal Data and Shared Personal Data against accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to personal data Processed by it, including as a minimum, the security measures described in Annex 3 and (inter alia) where appropriate:

the pseudonymisation and encryption of the University Personal Data and Shared Personal Data; guaranteeing the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability and resilience of processing systems and services; restoring the availability and access to the University Personal Data and Shared Personal Data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident; and

regularly testing, assessing and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organisational measures for ensuring the security of the processing of University Personal Data and Shared Personal Data. The Supplier shall notify the University immediately if it suspects or becomes aware of any actual, threatened or potential breach of security of the University Personal Data and/or Shared Personal Data, and shall ensure all such notices include full and complete details relating to such breach, in particular:

the nature and facts of such breach including the categories and number of the Personal Data records and, if applicable, Data Subjects concerned; the contact details of the data protection officer or other representative duly appointed by the Supplier from whom the University can obtain further information relating to such breach;

the likely consequences or potential consequences of such breach; and the measures taken or proposed to be taken by the Supplier and/or any Supplier Personnel to address such breach and to mitigate any possible adverse effects and the implementation dates for such measures.

The Supplier shall: to the extent permitted under Applicable Law, on the University’s request at any time (at no cost to the University) give the University a copy of all or part of the University Data then in the Supplier’s possession, custody or control, which is in electronic form, in such format as the University may require;

ensure that if any the University Data is disposed of, such disposal takes places in a secure manner such that the University Data is not recoverable; preserve so far as possible the security of the University Data and prevent any loss, destruction, disclosure, theft, manipulation or interception of the University Data; and

ensure that its anti-malware controls are deployed and maintained in accordance with Good Industry Practice and the Supplier’s IT policies, check for and delete any malicious materials from its systems and not intentionally or negligently transfer any malicious materials onto any the University systems or onto any media containing the University Data.

The Supplier shall at all times comply with ISO/IEC27001 or otherwise comply with Good Industry Practice relating to data protection, and implementation and maintenance of back-up systems and the Business Continuity Plan.

The Supplier shall at all times ensure that its IT systems are fit for the purpose of securing the University Data in accordance with Good Industry Practice and this Agreement and are regularly maintained and, if necessary, upgraded to ensure this and to ensure the effectiveness of technical and organisational measures for ensuring security of all processing of University Data. The Parties shall keep such technical and organisational measures under review and shall carry out such updates as they agree are appropriate throughout the Contract Term.

INDEMNITY The Supplier shall indemnify the University against: (i) all Liabilities arising out of or in connection with any breach by the Supplier and/or any Data Third Parties (as applicable) of this Schedule; and (ii) all amounts paid or payable by the University to a third party which would not have been paid or payable if the Supplier’s breach of this Schedule had not occurred.

text:
ITT316 Appointment of an Occupational Health Provider (Staff occupational health)
Clarification 1.
13 September 2024
Q1. Does TUPE apply, and if so, how can we obtain the details.
A1. No TUPE as we currently have another external supplier.
Q2. Is the financial envelope (£270,000) for the three, or anticipated 5 year duration
A2. This is for the 5 years, approx. £54,000 ex vat per annum
Q3. In the specification you ask for a telephone EAP service. Should this include sessions of
counselling, or are you looking for the advice line only
A3. Counselling to be included.
Q4. Please can you confirm the types of health surveillance the 150 colleagues require, and
when they are next due to be seen.
A4. Health Surveillance was completed in June 2024 so will not be needed again until summer
2025. It takes a few months to organise so we get the list of names together around April time,
send the questionnaires out in June, and carry out any face to face meetings in August.
The different types of health surveillance we require are: Audiometry, Colour vision, Drivers
medical, Hand Arm Vibration, Nigh Worker, Respiratory / Lung Function, Skin tests.
Q5. Please can you confirm how many IHR (pension) requests you have annually
A5. approx. 5 per year.
Q6. In section 3.1 of the ITT doc it says there are 57 questions, however I can only see 54 - for
the avoidance of doubt, please can you confirm if questions 55-57 are missing?
A6. The question numbers in 3.1 and 5.4 Table 2 are incorrect, the below table is correct.
Criteria Evidence Required Weighting
Pricing/Cost Appendix 8a (price list and Q7) 25%
Additional information on services and alternative suggestions
Fit for Purpose 20%
that would enhance our service e.g. details on portal (Q8 – 22)
Proposed SLAs, explanation of how they will provide our list of
Capability 35%
requirements (Q23 – 46)
See Section 5.7 & 3.1
Method Statement 10%
Details on how the project/contract will be delivered (Q47 – 54)
Social Impact See section 5.6 10%
Total 100%

Q7. The pricing schedule covers vaccinations. Please can you confirm the approx number of
vaccinations you would expect the new provider to deliver (and what types of vaccine)
A7. This will not be required
Q8. Is there space available on campus for the delivery of vaccines and health surveillance.
A8. Health surveillance is generally carried out via a questionnaire. Depending on the answers,
the staff member may then require a face-to-face meeting to carry out tests (audiology, lung
function, skin, etc….)
This is usually required for around 30 – 40 members of staff at the most. We agree the dates in
advance with a nurse, create a schedule and book one of the meeting rooms. The nurse will
have enough room to set up equipment and carry out the testing in the meeting room. It is
easier to carry this out on site.
Vaccinations - we will not need vaccinations provided under this contract.

Standard contractual clause on data protection (Using EU model template) A successful Tender will result in the contractor agreeing to the following special conditions, where applicable, companies external to the UK will also be expected to comply with all of the following based on the EU Model Contractual clauses :

Processing of personal data by the contracting authority For the purpose of Article II.9.1, (a) The data controller is [insert position of the data controller and name of the organisational entity (this is either the University or the organisation we are dealing with];

(b) The University data protection Policy and Procedures document is available here Processing of personal data by the contractor [For the purpose of Article II.9.2, (a) The subject matter and purpose of the processing of personal data by the contractor are [provide a short and concise description of the subject matter and purpose];

(b) The localisation of and access to the personal data processed by the contractor shall comply with the following: i.	the personal data shall only be processed within the territory of [the European Union and the European Economic Area and will not leave that territory;

ii.	the data shall only be held in data centres located with the territory of [the European Union and the European Economic Area; iii.	no access shall be given to such data outside of the European Union and the European Economic Area. Access to data may be given on a need-to-know basis only to authorised persons established in a country which has been recognised by the European Commission as providing adequate protection to personal data;

iv.	the contractor may not change the location of data processing without the prior written authorisation of the contracting authority; v.	any transfer of personal data to third countries or international organisations shall fully comply with the requirements laid down in Chapter V of Regulation (EU)2018/1725.]

General Conditions Processing of personal data by the contracting authority Any personal data included in or relating to this contract, including its implementation, shall be processed in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 2018/1725. Such data shall be  processed solely for the purposes  of the implementation, management and monitoring of    the contracting process by the data controller.

The contractor or any other person whose personal data is processed by the data controller in relation to this document has specific rights as a data subject under Chapter III (Articles 14-25) of Regulation (EU) No 2018/1725, in particular the right to access, rectify or erase their personal data and the right to restrict or, where applicable, the right to object to processing or the right to data portability.

Should the contractor or any other person whose personal data is processed in relation to this document have any queries concerning the processing of its personal data, it shall address itself to the data controller. They may also address themselves to  the  Data  Protection  Officer of the data controller. They have the right to lodge a complaint at any time to the relevant European Data Protection Supervisor - normally the UK Information Commissioner.

Details concerning the processing of personal data are available in the data protection documentation referred to in Article I.9. Processing of personal data by the contractor The processing of personal data by the contractor shall meet the requirements of Regulation (EU) No 2018/1725 and be processed solely for the purposes set out by the controller.

The contractor shall assist the controller for the fulfilment of the controller’s obligation to respond to requests for exercising rights of person whose personal data is processed  in relation to this document as laid  down  in  Chapter  III  (Articles  14-25)  of  Regulation  (EU) No 2018/1725. The contractor shall inform without delay the controller about such requests.

The contractor may act only on documented written instructions and under the supervision of the controller, in  particular with  regard to  the purposes of the processing, the categories      of data that may be processed, the recipients of the data and the means by which the data subject may exercise its rights.

The contractor shall grant personnel access to the data to the extent strictly necessary for the implementation, management and monitoring of the process covered by this document. The contractor must ensure that personnel authorised to process personal data have committed themselves to confidentiality or  is under appropriate statutory obligation of  confidentiality  in accordance with the provisions of Article II.8.

The contractor shall adopt appropriate technical and organisational security measures, giving due regard to the risks inherent in the processing and to the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing, in order to ensure, in particular, as appropriate:

the pseudonymisation and encryption of personal data; the ability to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability and resilience of processing systems and services; the ability to restore the availability and access to personal data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident;

a process for regularly testing, assessing and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organisational measures for ensuring the security of the processing; measures to protect personal data from accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of or access to personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed.

The contractor shall notify relevant personal data breaches to the controller without undue delay and at the latest within 48 hours after the contractor becomes aware of the breach. In such cases, the contractor shall provide the controller with at least the following information:

nature of the personal data breach including where possible, the categories and approximate number of data subjects concerned and the categories and approximate number of personal data records concerned. likely consequences of the breach;

measures taken or proposed to be taken to address the breach, including, where appropriate, measures to mitigate its possible adverse effects. The contractor shall immediately inform the data controller if, in its opinion, an instruction infringes Regulation (EU) 2018/1725, Regulation (EU) 2016/679, or other Union or Member State data protection provisions as referred to in the tender specifications.

The contractor shall assist the controller for the fulfilment of its obligations pursuant to Article 33 to 41 under Regulation (EU) 2018/1725 to: ensure compliance with its data protection obligations regarding the security of the processing, and the confidentiality of electronic communications and directories of users;

notify a personal data breach to the European Data Protection Supervisor; communicate a personal data breach without undue delay to the data subject, where applicable; carry out data protection impact assessments and prior consultations as necessary.

The contractor shall maintain a record of all data processing operations carried on behalf of the controller, transfers of personal data, security breaches, responses to requests for exercising rights of people whose personal data is processed and requests for access to personal data by third parties.

The contracting authority is subject to Protocol 7 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, particularly as regards the inviolability of archives (including the physical location of data and services as set out in Article I.9.2) and data security, which includes personal data held on behalf of the contracting authority in the premises of the contractor or subcontractor.

The contractor shall notify the contracting authority without delay of any legally binding request for disclosure of the personal data processed on behalf of the contracting authority made by any national public authority, including an authority from a third country. The contractor may not give such access without the prior written authorisation of the contracting authority.

The duration of processing of personal data by the contractor will not exceed the period referred to in Article II.24.2. Upon expiry of this period, the contractor shall, at the choice of the controller, return, without any undue delay in a commonly agreed format, all personal data processed on behalf of the controller and the copies thereof or shall effectively delete all personal data unless Union or national law requires a longer storage of personal data.

For the purpose of Article II.10, if part or all of the processing of personal data is subcontracted to a third party, the contractor shall pass on the obligations referred to in Articles I.9.2 and II.9.2 in writing to those parties, including subcontractors. At the request of the contracting authority, the contractor shall provide a document providing evidence of this commitment.

Appendix 3 - Standard Selection Questionnaire Template Potential Supplier Information and Exclusion Grounds: Part 1 and Part 2. The SQ template includes a self-declaration, made by you (the potential supplier), that none of the grounds for exclusion apply. If any of the grounds for exclusion do apply, there is an opportunity to explain any measures you have taken to demonstrate your reliability notwithstanding the existence of a ground for exclusion (we call this self-cleaning).

We require all the organisations that form part of your bidding group/consortium and each subcontractor that you are relying on to meet the selection criteria to provide a completed part 1 and part 2. This means that where you are joining a group of organisations, including joint ventures and partnerships, each organisation in that group must complete one of these self-declarations. Subcontractors that you rely on to meet the selection criteria, must also complete a self-declaration (although subcontractors that are not relied upon do not need to complete the self-declaration).

When completed, this form is to be sent back to the contact point given in the procurement documents along with the selection information requested in the procurement documentation. Supplier Selection Questions: Part 3

The procurement documents will provide instructions on the selection questions you need to respond to and how to submit those responses. If you are bidding on behalf of a group/consortium or you intend to use subcontractors, you should complete all of the selection questions on behalf of the group/consortium and/or any subcontractors.

If the relevant documentary evidence referred to in the Selection Questionnaire is not provided upon request and without delay, we reserve the right to exclude you from the procurement process, including where an award decision has already been notified, and award to another supplier.

Consequences of misrepresentation If you seriously misrepresent any factual information in filling in the Selection Questionnaire, and so induce an authority to enter into a contract, there may be significant consequences. You may be excluded from the procurement procedure, and from bidding for other contracts for three years. If a contract has been entered into you may be sued for damages and the contract may be rescinded. If fraud, or fraudulent intent, can be proved, you or your responsible officers may be prosecuted and convicted of the offence of fraud by false representation, and you must be excluded from further procurements for five years.

ITT316 Appointment of an Occupational Health Provider (Staff occupational health) Notes for completion The “authority” means the contracting authority, or anyone acting on behalf of the contracting authority, that is seeking to invite suitable candidates to participate in this procurement process.

“You” / “Your” refers to the potential supplier completing this standard Selection Questionnaire i.e. the legal entity responsible for the information provided. The term “potential supplier” is intended to cover any economic operator as defined by the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (referred to as the “regulations”) and could be a registered company; the lead contact for a group of economic operators; charitable organisation; Voluntary Community and Social Enterprise (VCSE); Special Purpose Vehicle; or other form of entity.

Please ensure that all questions are completed in full, and in the format requested. If the question does not apply to you, please state ‘N/A’. Should you need to provide additional information in response to the questions, please submit a clearly identified annex.

The authority recognises that arrangements set out in section 1.2 of the standard Selection Questionnaire, in relation to a group of economic operators (for example, a consortium) and/or use of subcontractors, may be subject to change and will, therefore, not be finalised until a later date. The lead contact should notify the authority immediately of any change in the proposed arrangements and ensure a completed part 1 and part 2 is submitted for any new organisation relied on to meet the selection criteria. The authority will make a revised assessment of the submission based on the updated information.

The authority may decline to consider bids (or otherwise exclude from participating in the procurement) from suppliers who are constituted or organised under the law of Russia or Belarus, or whose ‘Persons of Significant Control’ information states Russia or Belarus as the place of residency, unless the supplier (or any member of their supply chain they rely on to deliver the contract):

is registered in the UK or in a country the UK has a relevant international agreement with reciprocal rights of access to public procurement; and/or has significant business operations in the UK or in a country the UK has a relevant international agreement with reciprocal rights of access to public procurement.
For part 1 and part 2 every member of your bidding group/consortium, and any subcontractor that is being relied on to meet the selection criteria, must complete and submit the self-declaration.

For the mandatory exclusion grounds only (Q2.1(a)), you must complete the declaration for all relevant persons and entities. There are two categories of persons and entities: members of your administrative, management or supervisory board;

entities and persons who have powers of representation, decision or control. You must decide, depending on the nature and structure of the entity or person who is bidding, which entities and persons this applies to in your particular circumstances. Clearly, members of your administrative, management or supervisory board should be easily identifiable and will cover company directors (or equivalent for other types of corporate entities) and members of an executive board.

The second category of those with powers of representation, decision or control, is likely to be more complicated. As an illustration, entities or persons with 25% or more shareholding (or equivalent for other types of corporate entities) are likely to have powers or representation, decision or control, although those with a lower shareholding may still have the relevant powers depending on their particular rights.  Similarly, your ultimate parent company (or equivalent for other types of corporate entities) is likely to have powers of representation, decision or control.  Depending on your particular structure, intermediate parent companies who do not have a direct shareholding, directors or members of an executive board of your immediate parent company (for example in the case of an SPV set up specifically to bid for a particular contract), and holders of mortgages or liens may be covered. It isn’t necessary to identify which entities and persons you think are covered but you must be satisfied that your declaration is made in respect of all of those that are covered.

The Public Procurement Review Service allows government suppliers and potential government suppliers to raise concerns anonymously about unfair public sector procurement practice. The government can then investigate and resolve these concerns for contracting authorities as listed in Schedule 1 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015. To use the Public Procurement Review Service, read the terms and email publicprocurementreview@cabinetoffice.gov.uk or phone 0345 010 3503.

I am aware of the consequences of serious misrepresentation. Section 8 – Selection Stage Requirements These questions will be scored as detailed in section 5 Evaluation of Tenders. Important Notes

When a requirement is stated, the Applicant shall identify clearly whether it can meet the requirement and provide information to evidence how this requirement is met.  Any limitations in the Applicant’s ability to meet the requirement shall be detailed.

Except where the question specifies the response requirement is a Yes/No answer, a simple “Yes” or “No” response will not be considered adequate. In addition, references to a separate document would not be considered sufficient but can be used to back up a response providing it is relevant and clearly labelled with the corresponding number.
Where appropriate, Applicants may wish to include screen shots for illustrative purposes. However, these shall only be used to enhance a response and shall never replace a purely textual reply.

When replying to this section, the Applicant shall not change the individual reference number of the requirements. However, the response can be submitted in a different format e.g., PDF or PowerPoint but must be clearly labelled to make it clear as to which question it relates.

The University will exclude a potential supplier, where it fails any of the Yes/No Pass/Fail questions.

provided upon request and without delay, we reserve the right to exclude you from the
procurement process, including where an award decision has already been notified, and
award to another supplier.
Consequences of misrepresentation
If you seriously misrepresent any factual information in filling in the Selection
Questionnaire, and so induce an authority to enter into a contract, there may be significant
consequences. You may be excluded from the procurement procedure, and from bidding
for other contracts for three years. If a contract has been entered into you may be sued for
damages and the contract may be rescinded. If fraud, or fraudulent intent, can be proved,
you or your responsible officers may be prosecuted and convicted of the offence of fraud
by false representation, and you must be excluded from further procurements for five
years.

Notes for completion
1. The “authority” means the contracting authority, or anyone acting on behalf of the
contracting authority, that is seeking to invite suitable candidates to participate in this
procurement process.
2. “You” / “Your” refers to the potential supplier completing this standard Selection
Questionnaire i.e. the legal entity responsible for the information provided. The term
“potential supplier” is intended to cover any economic operator as defined by the Public
Contracts Regulations 2015 (referred to as the “regulations”) and could be a registered
company; the lead contact for a group of economic operators; charitable organisation;
Voluntary Community and Social Enterprise (VCSE); Special Purpose Vehicle; or other
form of entity.
3. Please ensure that all questions are completed in full, and in the format requested.
If the question does not apply to you, please state ‘N/A’. Should you need to provide
additional information in response to the questions, please submit a clearly identified
annex.
4. The authority recognises that arrangements set out in section 1.2 of the standard
Selection Questionnaire, in relation to a group of economic operators (for example, a
consortium) and/or use of subcontractors, may be subject to change and will, therefore,
not be finalised until a later date. The lead contact should notify the authority immediately
of any change in the proposed arrangements and ensure a completed part 1 and part 2 is
submitted for any new organisation relied on to meet the selection criteria. The authority
will make a revised assessment of the submission based on the updated information.
5. The authority may decline to consider bids (or otherwise exclude from
participating in the procurement) from suppliers who are constituted or organised under
the law of Russia or Belarus, or whose ‘Persons of Significant Control’ information states
Russia or Belarus as the place of residency, unless the supplier (or any member of their
supply chain they rely on to deliver the contract):
• is registered in the UK or in a country the UK has a relevant international
agreement with reciprocal rights of access to public procurement; and/or
• has significant business operations in the UK or in a country the UK has a
relevant international agreement with reciprocal rights of access to public
procurement.
6. For part 1 and part 2 every member of your bidding group/consortium, and any
subcontractor that is being relied on to meet the selection criteria, must complete and
submit the self-declaration.
7. For the mandatory exclusion grounds only (Q2.1(a)), you must complete the
declaration for all relevant persons and entities. There are two categories of persons and
entities:
• members of your administrative, management or supervisory board;
• entities and persons who have powers of representation, decision or control.
You must decide, depending on the nature and structure of the entity or person who is
bidding, which entities and persons this applies to in your particular circumstances.
Clearly, members of your administrative, management or supervisory board should be
easily identifiable and will cover company directors (or equivalent for other types of
corporate entities) and members of an executive board.
The second category of those with powers of representation, decision or control, is
likely to be more complicated. As an illustration, entities or persons with 25% or more
shareholding (or equivalent for other types of corporate entities) are likely to have

powers or representation, decision or control, although those with a lower
shareholding may still have the relevant powers depending on their particular rights.
Similarly, your ultimate parent company (or equivalent for other types of corporate
entities) is likely to have powers of representation, decision or control. Depending on
your particular structure, intermediate parent companies who do not have a direct
shareholding, directors or members of an executive board of your immediate parent
company (for example in the case of an SPV set up specifically to bid for a particular
contract), and holders of mortgages or liens may be covered. It isn’t necessary to
identify which entities and persons you think are covered but you must be satisfied that
your declaration is made in respect of all of those that are covered.
8. The Public Procurement Review Service allows government suppliers and
potential government suppliers to raise concerns anonymously about unfair public sector
procurement practice. The government can then investigate and resolve these concerns
for contracting authorities as listed in Schedule 1 of the Public Contracts Regulations
2015. To use the Public Procurement Review Service, read the terms and email
publicprocurementreview@cabinetoffice.gov.uk or phone 0345 010 3503.

University of Northampton Introduction This ITT is made available on condition that it is to be used in connection with tendering for the opportunity. By submitting a tender response, the Tenderer accepts and will be bound by the provisions of this ITT, its appendices and will comply with applicable laws, codes of practice, statutory guidance, and also any University policies relevant to the Project located at the following link: https://www.northampton.ac.uk/about-us/governance-and-management/management/university-policies-procedures-and-regulations/

For the purposes of the Appointment the Employer will be the University or a wholly owned subsidiary of the University and any reference to the University in this ITT shall be deemed, where the context requires, to include a reference to a wholly owned subsidiary of the University.

Specification and Scope of Services The University of Northampton is seeking an Occupational Health accredited single provider who is approved by Northamptonshire Local Government Pension Scheme Administrator Authority who can deliver a full Occupational Health service to approximately 2500 employees.  Services required include pre-employment checks, management referrals, health surveillance, an employee assistance programme, mediation, counselling programmes.

We would require consolidated invoicing at the end of each month via the main supplier including any services that may be outsourced. We require management information reports that are tailored to our requirements due to the need to report specific information to our Board of Governors.  For example, reporting will need to be based on the academic year which will not be the same as the contract year. Reports will need cover usage and if possible, the ability to break down to a Faculty or Department level.

The most regular services used are as follows with approximate numbers based on usage in 2023/2024: Placement questionnaires (Approx 300 per annum) Placement consultations (Approx 25 per annum) Management referrals/consultations (Approx 35 per annum)

Telephone Employee Assistance Programme for 2500 employees Health surveillance checks for approx 150 employees We also require: Provision of GDPR compliant reports with recommendations Regular reports (at least quarterly) on usage, referrals etc.

A Key contact SLA’s regarding timeframes as part of contract OH/Wellbeing online portal (desirable) The below are ad-hoc requirements: GP/ Consultant report requests and subsequent report to the University (2)

Pension GP/ Consultant report requests and subsequent report to the University Pension Assessments Pension Appeals Counselling Programmes Individual face to face Counselling appointments Mediation sessions Access to health and wellness campaigns and materials

Specific health surveillance requirements are as follows: The provision of a secure on-line portal to manage communications with, and be made available to individual UON staff members for health surveillance purposes.

To offer a broad range of health screening solutions in the form of on-line questionnaires, on-line assessments and in-person assessments including as a minimum requirement, audiometry, hand-arm vibration (HAVS) Tiers 3-5, vision screening, muscular-skeletal, lung function testing, skin assessments (dermatitis), work at height and driver medical assessments.

To attend university facilities on agreed dates to undertake health screening activities, including the flexibility to undertake ‘out of hours’ assessments for certain roles, e.g., night workers, lone workers. Provide nominated contacts for managing health surveillance arrangements.

Provision of reporting on health surveillance services delivery (within GDPR frameworks). Key Performance Indicators & Service Level Agreements (KPIs & SLAs) The following SLA’s are deemed to be pivotal and will be measured via regular management information and supplier management scorecard meetings.

Appendix 2 - Social Impact Social Impact has many overlapping definitions but is taken by the university to mean “the cumulative positive effects of the University on the social and economic fabric, health and wellbeing of communities we serve “.

The University of Northampton is totally and publicly committed to being socially innovative to deliver social impact. For us, social innovation is bringing new thinking to help tackle new problems. The research and teaching our academic staff do, and the extra curricula activities we provide, are designed to develop the skills and knowledge of our students so they can be social innovators in whatever future careers they have. We also expect to work with our strategic partners and suppliers to identify and implement socially innovative ways in which we can have social impact.

We believe that by working with our partners we can have a social impact in many ways. Table 1 (below) gives just some of the ways in which the University makes a positive difference to people and the environment.
